revision.comment: v1.43 - Repaired 1 link to disambiguation page - [[WP:DPL|(You can help)]] - [[William Lambert (cricketer)]]
revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1811 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * [[Tom Cribb]] retains his English championship, defeating American [[Tom Molineaux]] on 28 September in the 11th round of a highly anticipated return bout.<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/cribb.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Tom Cribb] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/5gVUt4ZMo?url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/cribb.htm |date=2009-05-04 }}. Retrieved on 18 October 2009.</ref>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * In time for the start of the 1811 season, [[Marylebone Cricket Club]] (MCC) reluctantly follows [[Thomas Lord]] to his new [[Lord's Middle Ground|Middle Ground]], the lease on the original [[Lord's Old Ground]] having expired. MCC are resident at the Middle Ground for the next three years. * Only one [[first-class cricket|first-class]] match is recorded as the [[Napoleonic War]] takes its toll of cricket's manpower and investment. '''England''' * Most runs<ref name="cards">Note that scorecards created in the first quarter of the 19th century are not necessarily accurate or complete; therefore any summary of runs, wickets or catches can only represent the '''known''' totals and the missing data prevents effective computation of averages</ref> – [[William Lambert (cricketer, born 1779)|William Lambert]] 51 * Most wickets<ref name="cards"/> – [[Thomas Howard (English cricketer)|Thomas Howard]] 8
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Trophonius * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Phantom (horse)|Phantom]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Sorcery (horse)|Sorcery]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Soothsayer (horse)|Soothsayer]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year to 1850}}
[[Category:Sports by year|1811]] [[Category:1811 in sports| ]]

{{Year box}} '''1836 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * [[James Burke (boxer)|James Burke]] decides to try his luck in America and so the English Championship issue lies unresolved for another three years.<ref name="JB">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/burke-j.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – James Burke]. Retrieved on 7 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * 17 June — a meeting in Brighton establishes a "Sussex Cricket Fund" to support county matches and it is from this organisation that [[Sussex County Cricket Club]] is formally constituted in 1839 * 11–12 July — the inaugural [[North v South]] fixture is held at [[Lord's Cricket Ground|Lord's]] between teams representing the [[North of England cricket team|North]] and [[South of England cricket team|South]] of England.<ref>[http://www.cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Scorecards/0/556.html CricketArchive scorecard]</ref> The North wins by 6 wickets. '''England''' * Most runs – [[Alfred Mynn]] 407 @ 33.91 (HS 125*) * Most wickets – [[William Lillywhite]] 51 (BB 9–?)
==[[Horse racing]]== '''Events''' * The inaugural running of the Great Liverpool Steeplechase takes place at [[Aintree Racecourse]]. Three years later, it will become the [[Grand National]]. The first winner is [[The Duke (racehorse)|The Duke]] ridden by [[Captain Martin Becher]], after whom [[Becher's Brook]] will be named. '''England''' * [[1836 Grand Liverpool Steeplechase|Grand National]]<ref>Officially known as the Great Liverpool Steeplechase from 1836 to 1838.</ref> – [[The Duke (racehorse)|The Duke]] * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Destiny (horse)|Destiny]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Bay Middleton (horse)|Bay Middleton]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Bay Middleton (horse)|Bay Middleton]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Cyprian * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Elis (horse)|Elis]]
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 17 June — the [[The Boat Race 1836|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]], first held in 1829, is revived and the 2nd race takes place on the [[River Thames|Thames]] between [[Westminster]] and [[Putney]]. [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] records its first win in the event.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year to 1850}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1836 in sports| ]]

{{Year box}} '''1850 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Athletics (track and field)|Athletics]]== '''Events''' * 22–23 October — [[William Penny Brookes]], a local doctor, organises the first [[Wenlock Olympian Games]] in England.<ref name="CB">{{cite web|url=http://www.wenlock-olympian-society.org.uk/history/wpb/first-olympian-games.shtml |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-02-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120414172159/http://www.wenlock-olympian-society.org.uk/history/wpb/first-olympian-games.shtml |archivedate=2012-04-14 |df= }}.</ref> These later inspire Pierre, Baron de Coubertin to establish the international Olympian games that continue to this day. * November — Undergraduates at [[Exeter College, Oxford|Exeter College]] in the [[University of Oxford]] arrange a "foot grind" (a cross-country steeplechase), the first organised university athletic event in Britain.<ref>{{cite book|first=Montague|last=Shearman|title=Athletics and Football|location=London|publisher=Longman|year=1887}}</ref>
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 5 June — [[William Thompson (boxer)|William "Bendigo" Thompson]] defends his English Championship against [[Tom Paddock]] at Mildenhall. After winning the bout on the disqualification of Paddock after 49 rounds, Thompson announces his retirement from the ring.<ref name="WT">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/thompson.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Bendigo]. Retrieved on 7 November 2009.</ref> * 17 December — Tom Paddock fights [[William Perry (boxer)|William Perry]] at Woking Common. After 27 rounds, Paddock is disqualified after striking Perry on the neck while Perry was walking to his corner. Perry claims the vacant English Championship.<ref name="WP">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/perry.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – William Perry]. Retrieved on 7 November 2009.</ref> * American champion [[Tom Hyer]] challenges Perry to what would be a world title fight but Perry does not respond.<ref name="TH">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/hyer-t.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Tom Hyer]. Retrieved on 7 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * Re-emergence of [[Middlesex county cricket teams|Middlesex]] as a county team, largely through the interest of the [[V E Walker|Walker family]] that will eventually found the present [[Middlesex County Cricket Club]] '''England''' * Most runs – [[John Wisden]] 374 @ 18.70 (HS 100) * Most wickets – [[John Wisden]] 103 @ 14.07 (BB 10–?)
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1850 Grand National|Grand National]] – Abd-El-Kader * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Lady Orford * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Pitsford * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Voltigeur (horse)|Voltigeur]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Rhedycina * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Voltigeur (horse)|Voltigeur]]
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * The [[Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] is not held this year
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year to 1850}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1850 in sports| ]]

{{Year box}} '''1861 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * [[National Association of Base Ball Players]] champion – [[Brooklyn Atlantics]] '''Events''' * The [[NABBP|National Association]] establishes the December annual meeting, a change from March, meeting twice during calendar 1860. Membership slips from 59 to 55 clubs and then the outbreak of the [[American Civil War]] in the spring sharply cuts both inter-city travel and the number of matches played in greater New York City. Some clubs practically disband.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 18 June — [[Jem Mace]] defeats [[Sam Hurst]] in eight rounds at Medway Island to win the Heavyweight Championship of England. Hurst retires from boxing.<ref name="JM">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/mace-j.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Jem Mace]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref> * [[John C. Heenan]] retains the Championship of America but there is no record of any fights involving him in 1861.<ref name="JH">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/heenan.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – John C. Heenan]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * 20 October — [[English cricket team in Australia in 1861–62|the first English team to tour Australia]] sets sail from Liverpool. The team is captained by [[H. H. Stephenson]]. No first-class matches are played. '''England''' * Most runs – [[Robert Carpenter (cricketer)|Robert Carpenter]] 883 @ 30.44 (HS 106) * Most wickets – [[Edgar Willsher]] 87 @ 11.65 (BB 8–27)
==[[Football]]== '''Events''' * Foundation of [[Richmond F.C.|Richmond FC]] and [[Sale Sharks]] which are two of the oldest senior [[rugby union]] clubs
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1861 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Tom Morris, Sr.|Tom Morris senior]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''Events''' * The inaugural running of the [[Melbourne Cup]] in Australia is won by [[Archer (horse)|Archer]]. The Melbourne Cup is a race for three-year-olds and above, over a distance of 3,200 metres (approximately two miles). '''England''' * [[1861 Grand National|Grand National]] – Jealousy * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Nemesis * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Diophantus * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Kettledrum (horse)|Kettledrum]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Brown Duchess * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – Caller Ou '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – [[Archer (horse)|Archer]] '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Wild Irishman
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 23 March — [[Oxford University Boat Club|Oxford]] wins the 18th [[The Boat Race 1861|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] '''Other events''' * [[Harvard–Yale Regatta]] – ''not contested 1861 to 1863''
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1851 – 1900}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1861 in sports| ]]

{{Year box}} '''1871 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – none '''Events''' * The [[1871 college football season]] is the only one since the first season in [[1869 college football season|1869]] until the present day that no games are played in the entire season.<ref>[http://www.collegefootballblog.org/2006/03/national_champions_18691879.html "National Champions: 1869–1879"]. Jimmy Atkinson. ''Retrospective National Championship Project''. College Football Blog. 20 March 2006.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-game.org/history-waltercamp.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-04-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130405055140/http://www.the-game.org/history-waltercamp.htm |archivedate=2013-04-05 |df= }}. history-waltercamp.htm (''the-game.org''). <!-- archive fileserver is down; URL seems to be http://web.archive.org/web/20130405055140/http://www.the-game.org/history-waltercamp.htm --></ref> Thus 1871 is the only year since play began in which no [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|college football national champion]] can be named, retrospectively or otherwise.
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * Inaugural [[FA Cup]] competition begins with four matches played on 11 November. The 15 clubs entering the competition are all amateur and mainly from the London area: [[Barnes R.F.C.|Barnes]], Civil Service, [[Clapham Rovers F.C.|Clapham Rovers]], [[Crystal Palace F.C. (1861)|Crystal Palace (1861)]], Donnington School, Hampstead Heathens, Harrow Chequers, Hitchin, Maidenhead, Marlow, Reigate, Priory, [[Royal Engineers A.F.C.|Royal Engineers]], [[Upton Park F.C.|Upton Park]], [[Wanderers F.C.|The Wanderers]] and [[Queen's Park FC|Queen's Park]] (Glasgow). : The Wanderers win the Cup on 16 March 1872.
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * [[National Association of Professional Base Ball Players]] champion – [[Philadelphia Athletics (National League)|Philadelphia Athletics]] '''Events''' * March — ten [[NABBP]] clubs found the [[National Association of Professional Base Ball Players]], the first [[professional sports league organization|professional sports league]]. (Today it is commonly considered the first [[Major League Baseball|major league]] and usually called simply the "National Association" or "NA".) Thirty-three clubs establish a parallel amateur NAABBP that withers away. * There are nine NA teams in the field and [[Philadelphia Athletics (National Association)|Athletic]] of Philadelphia wins the championship in the final game, 30 October.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * With the main American Championship title claimant [[Mike McCoole]] inactive this year, attention focuses on two fights between [[Jem Mace]] and [[Joe Coburn]]. Both fights are drawn and Mace continues to state his claim to the American Championship. However, having suffered a hand injury in his second fight with Coburn, Mace relinquishes all his title claims and returns to exhibition boxing.<ref name="JM">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/mace-j.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Jem Mace]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref> * McCoole is now generally regarded as the champion by default, his main challenger being [[Tom Allen (boxer)|Tom Allen]] who was defeated by McCoole in 1869.<ref name="MM">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/mccoole.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Mike McCoole]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * [[Derbyshire County Cricket Club|Derbyshire]] plays its inaugural [[first-class cricket|first-class]] match v. [[Lancashire County Cricket Club|Lancashire]] at [[Old Trafford Cricket Ground|Old Trafford]] on 26 & 27 May. '''England''' * Most runs – [[W. G. Grace]] 2,739 @ 78.25 (HS 268), a staggering feat on the pitches of the time. [[Richard Daft]] has the next highest average among batsmen playing 10 innings or more, with 37.66, less than half of Grace's figure. [[Harry Jupp]] has the next highest runs aggregate, with 1,068. Grace makes ten centuries in the season, while no other player can manage more than one. * Most wickets – [[James Southerton]] 151 @ 15.72 (BB 8–63)
==[[Gaelic football]]== * During the 1860s and 1870s, rugby and association football have started to become popular in Ireland. According to Gaelic football historian [[Jack Mahon (Gaelic footballer)|Jack Mahon]], [[caid (sport)|caid]] has begun to give way to a "rough-and-tumble game" which even allows tripping. * [[County Limerick]] is the stronghold of the native game around this time and the Commercials Club, founded by employees of Cannock's Drapery Store, is one of the first to impose a set of rules that is later adopted by other clubs in the county.
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[The Open Championship|British Open]] – no competition. * The Open has been administered since 1860 by [[Prestwick Golf Club]] but controversy prevents the tournament being held in 1871, the only exception outside the two World Wars. Finally it is agreed that Prestwick will henceforth organise the tournament jointly with [[The Royal & Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews]] and [[The Honourable Company of Edinburgh Golfers]].
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1871 Grand National|Grand National]] – The Lamb (second win, having also won in 1868) * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Hannah (horse)|Hannah]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Bothwell * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Favonius (horse)|Favonius]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Hannah * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – Hannah '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – The Pearl '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Floss '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – The Doe * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Maid of Athens '''USA''' * [[Belmont Stakes]] – [[Harry Bassett (horse)|Harry Bassett]]
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 1 April — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 28th [[The Boat Race 1871|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] '''Other''' * There is no [[Harvard–Yale Regatta]]. From the third Race in 1859, the only exceptions outside major wars are 1871 and 1896.
==[[Rugby football]]== '''Events''' * 26 January — the [[Rugby Football Union]] (RFU) is founded at the Pall Mall Restaurant, which is situated near [[Trafalgar Square]] at 1 Cockspur Street, London. The formation of the RFU establishes the "handling game" as a different sport to the "[[association football|dribbling game]]" that is increasingly being played under the auspices of [[the Football Association]]. * 21 clubs are represented at the meeting: Blackheath, Richmond, Ravenscourt Park, West Kent, Marlborough Nomads, Wimbledon Hornets, Gipsies, Civil Service, Law Club, Wellington College, Guy's Hospital, Flamingoes, Clapham Rovers, Harlequins, King's College, St Paul's School, Queen's House, Lausanne, Addison, Mohicans, [[Belsize Park Rugby Football Club|Belsize Park]]. Algernon Rutter of Richmond is elected the first president. A committee is selected to produce a definitive national set of Rugby Football laws. * 27 March — the [[1871 England versus Scotland rugby union match|first ever official international fixture]] in any kind of football takes place with a rugby football game between Scotland and England. Scotland (i.e., Scottish members of the RFU) defeats England (i.e., English members of the RFU) by 1 goal & 1 try to 1 try at Raeburn Place in Edinburgh. The match is played by teams of 20–a–side and the game lasts for 50 minutes each way. * Foundation of [[Worcester RFC]]
==[[Yacht racing]]== '''America's Cup''' * The [[New York Yacht Club]] retains the [[America's Cup]] as ''[[Columbia (1871 yacht)|Columbia]]'' and its substitute ''[[Sappho (yacht)|Sappho]]'' defeat British challenger ''Livonia'' of the Royal Harwich Yacht Club.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1851 – 1900}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1871 in sports| ]]

{{Year box}} [[Image:Charlotte Cooper.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Wimbledon tennis champion [[Charlotte Cooper Sterry]]]] '''1901 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''Professional championships''' * [[Western Pennsylvania Professional Football Circuit|Western Pennsylvania Championship]] – [[1901 Homestead Library & Athletic Club football team|Homestead Library & Athletic Club]]
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * [[The Football League]] – [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] 45 points, [[Sunderland FC|Sunderland]] 43, [[Notts County]] 40, [[Nottingham Forest]] 39, [[Bury FC|Bury]] 39, [[Newcastle United]] 38 * [[1901 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Tottenham Hotspur]] 3–1 [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] at [[Crystal Palace National Sports Centre|Crystal Palace]], London (replay following 2–2 draw at Crystal Palace). * Tottenham Hotspur is the first (and to date only) [[non-League football|non-League]] club to win the FA Cup since the foundation of the Football League. * [[Brighton & Hove Albion FC]] founded. '''Hungary''' * Formation of the [[Hungarian Football Federation]] (i.e., the Magyar Labdarúgó Szövetség or MLSZ) '''Peru''' * [[Alianza Lima]], officially founded on February 15.{{citation needed|date=February 2016}} '''Scotland''' * [[Scottish Football League]] – [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] * [[1901 Scottish Cup Final|Scottish Cup final]] – [[Heart of Midlothian F.C.|Hearts]] 4–3 [[Glasgow Celtic|Celtic]] at [[Ibrox Stadium|Ibrox Park]]
==[[Athletics (sport)|Athletics]]== * [[Jack Caffery (track and field athlete)|Jack Caffery]] wins the fifth running of the [[Boston Marathon]].<ref name="BAA 1901-1905">{{cite web |url=http://www.baa.org/races/boston-marathon/boston-marathon-history/race-summaries/1901-1905.aspx |title=Boston Marathon History: 1901-1905 |first= |last= |author=Boston Athletic Association |authorlink=Boston Athletic Association |coauthors= |date= |month= |year=2011 |work=www.baa.org |publisher=Boston Athletic Association |location=Boston |page= |pages= |at= |language= |trans-title=|format= |doi= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |accessdate=March 2, 2011 |quote= |ref= |separator= |postscript=}}</ref>
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''VFL Premiership''' * [[Essendon Football Club|Essendon]] wins the 5th [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership – Essendon 6.7 (43) d [[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood]] 2.4 (16) at [[Lake Oval]]
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * [[National League]] championship – [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] * [[American League]] championship – [[Chicago White Sox]] '''Events''' * The [[American League]] repudiates its minor status and competes with the [[National League]] as a second major league. The AL abandons four western cities for Washington, Baltimore, Philadelphia and Boston. It signs about 30 prominent NL players before the season begins. * The [[National League]] violates its constitution in the summer and there will be no major-minor agreement until the [[1903 in baseball|1903 season]]. * December – numerous minor leagues establish their own National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, commonly called [[Minor League Baseball]] (1902 to date).
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * [[Barbados Joe Walcott]] wins the [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship. He is ranked by [[Nat Fleischer]] and [[Charley Rose]] as the #1 All-Time Welterweight; other sports personalities such as [[Tad Dorgan]], [[Tom O'Rourke (boxing manager)|Tom O'Rourke]], [[Dan Morgan (boxing manager)|Dan Morgan]] and [[Jimmy Johnston]] call him "the greatest pound for pound fighter who ever lived".<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/walcott-j.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Barbados Joe Walcott]</ref> * [[Young Corbett II]] wins the [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship, defeating [[Terry McGovern (boxer)|"Terrible" Terry McGovern]] with a second round knockout * The vacant [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship is claimed first by [[Harry Harris (boxer)|Harry Harris]], who fails to defend it and increases his weight, so making himself ineligible. The title is then awarded to [[Harry Forbes]] following his second round knockout of Danny Dougherty '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[James J. Jeffries]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Tommy Ryan]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[William "Matty" Matthews]] → [[James "Rube" Ferns]] → [[Barbados Joe Walcott]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Frank Erne]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Terry McGovern (boxer)|"Terrible" Terry McGovern]] → [[Young Corbett II]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – title vacant → [[Harry Harris (boxer)|Harry Harris]] → title vacant → [[Harry Forbes]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * No cricket is played in South Africa due to the [[Boer War]]. '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club|Yorkshire]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – [[Durham County Cricket Club|Durham]] * Most runs – [[Bobby Abel]] 3309 @ 55.15 (HS 247) * Most wickets – [[Wilfred Rhodes]] 251 @ 15.12 (BB 8–53) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year]] – [[Len Braund]], [[Charlie McGahey]], [[Frank Mitchell (sportsman born 1872)|Frank Mitchell]], [[Willie Quaife]], [[Johnny Tyldesley]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[Victoria cricket team|Victoria]] * Most runs – [[Clem Hill]] 620 @ 103.33 (HS 365*) * Most wickets – [[Jack Saunders (cricketer, born 1876)|Jack Saunders]] 29 @ 17.13 (BB 6–70) and [[Joe Travers]] 29 @ 20.75 (BB 9–30) '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular|Bombay Presidency]] – [[Parsees cricket team|Parsees]] '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – not contested '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – [[Trinidad and Tobago cricket team|Trinidad and Tobago]]
==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * [[1901 World Figure Skating Championships|World Men's Champion]] – [[Ulrich Salchow]] (Sweden)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1901 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[James Braid (golfer)|James Braid]] * [[1901 US Open (golf)|US Open]] – [[Willie Anderson (golfer)|Willie Anderson]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[Harold Hilton]] * [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|US Amateur]] – [[Walter Travis]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[Grand National]] – Grudon * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Aida (horse)|Aida]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Handicapper (horse)|Handicapper]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Volodyovski]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Cap and Bells II]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Doricles]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Revenue '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – John Ruskin '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Tipperary Boy * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Carrigavalla '''USA''' * [[1901 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – His Eminence * [[Preakness Stakes]] – [[The Parader]] * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Commando
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Stanley Cup''' * [[Winnipeg Victorias]] defeats defending champion [[Montreal Shamrocks]] in a Cup challenge, two games to nil * Winnipeg Victorias wins the [[Manitoba Hockey Association]] (MHA) title over the Winnipeg Hockey Club and successfully defends the Stanley Cup title * [[Ottawa Hockey Club]] wins the [[Canadian Amateur Hockey League]] (CAHL) championship but declines to challenge Winnipeg for the Stanley Cup
==[[Lacrosse]]== '''Events''' * [[Donald Mann|Sir Donald Mann]] donates the [[Mann Cup]]. * [[Gilbert Elliot-Murray-Kynynmound, 4th Earl of Minto|Lord Minto]], the [[Governor General of Canada]], donates the [[Minto Cup]]. * Ottawa Capitals win the first [[Mann Cup]] and the first [[Minto Cup]].
==[[Motor racing]]== '''Paris–Berlin Trail''' * The Paris–Berlin Trail is run on 27–29 June over 1105 km and won by [[Henri Fournier]] (France) driving a [[Mors (automobile)|Mors]] in a time of 15:33:06. The race is in retrospect sometimes referred to as the ''VI Grand Prix de l'ACF''.<ref name="TD"/> '''Paris–Bordeaux Trail''' * The Paris–Bordeaux Trail is run on 29 May over 527.1 km and won by [[Henri Fournier]] (France) driving a [[Mors (automobile)|Mors]] in a time of 6:10:44. The race incorporates the Gordon Bennett Cup (see below).<ref name="TD">[http://www.teamdan.com/archive/gen/upto1903/1901.html 1901 Grand Prix and Paris Races]. Retrieved on 7 September 2009.</ref> '''Gordon Bennett Cup''' * The second [[Gordon Bennett Cup in auto racing|Gordon Bennett Cup]] is run from Paris to Bordeaux in conjunction with the Paris–Bordeaux Trail (see above) and won by Léonce Girardot (France) driving a [[Panhard|Panhard-Levassor]]. '''Circuit du Sud-Ouest''' * The ''[[Pau Grand Prix#History|Circuit du Sud-Ouest]]'' was run in Pau. Some [[English language|anglophone]] sources wrongly call it the 'Pau Grand Prix'. This may stem from a mistranslation of the contemporary French sources such as the magazine ''La France Auto'' of March 1901.<ref name="La France Auto Mar 1901">[http://forums.autosport.com/lofiversion/index.php/t57839.html Autosport, The Nostalgia Forum, Robert Dick quoting (translating) from ''La France Automobile'', March 1901]</ref> It was run in four classes around the streets of Pau. The ''Grand Prix du Palais d’Hiver'' was the name of the prizes awarded for the lesser classes ('Light cars' and 'Voiturettes'). The ''Grand Prix de Pau'' was the name of the prize awarded for the 'Heavy' (fastest) class. Thus [[Maurice Farman]] was awarded the 'Grand Prix de Pau' for his overall victory in the ''Circuit du Sud-Ouest'' driving a [[Panhard|Panhard 24 hp]]. Additionally the ''Grand Prix du Palais d’Hiver'' (400 à 650 kg 'Light car' class) was awarded to [[Henri Farman]] ([[Darracq and Company London|Darracq]]); the second ''Grand Prix du Palais d’Hiver'' for the under 400 kg ''Voiturettes''class was awarded to [[Louis Renault (industrialist)|Louis Renault]] ([[Renault]]); the ''Prix du Béarn'' was awarded to Osmont in a '[[De Dion-Bouton|De Dion]]' tricycle.<ref> ([http://forums.autosport.com/lofiversion/index.php/t57839.html Autosport, The Nostalgia Forum, Robert Dick quoting (translating) from ''La France Automobile'', March 1901] ([http://www.kolumbus.fi/leif.snellman/gpw1.htm ''Grand Prix Winners 1895–1949'' by Hans Etzrodt Part 1 1895–1916])</ref>
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 30 March — [[Oxford University Boat Club|Oxford]] wins the 58th [[The Boat Race 1901|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby league]]== '''England''' * [[Rugby Football League Championship|Championship]] – ''not contested'' * [[Challenge Cup|Challenge Cup final]] – [[Batley Bulldogs|Batley]] 6–0 [[Warrington Wolves|Warrington]] at [[Headingley Rugby Stadium]], [[Leeds]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Lancashire League Championship]] – [[Oldham R.L.F.C.|Oldham]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Yorkshire League Championship]] – [[Bradford Park Avenue A.F.C.|Bradford F.C.]]
==[[Rugby union]]== '''Home Nations Championship''' * 19th [[1901 Home Nations Championship|Home Nations Championship]] series is won by [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]]
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * [[1901 World Allround Speed Skating Championships|Men's All-round Champion]] – Franz Frederik Wathén (Russia)
==[[Tennis]]== '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Arthur Gore (tennis)|Arthur Gore]] (GB) defeats [[Reginald Doherty]] (GB) 4–6 7–5 6–4 6–4 * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Charlotte Cooper Sterry]] defeats [[Blanche Bingley Hillyard]] 6–2 6–2 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[André Vacherot]] defeats [[Paul Lebreton]]: details unknown * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – [[P. Girod]] defeats Leroux (scores unknown) '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[William Larned]] defeats [[Beals Wright]] 6–2 6–8 6–4 6–4 * [[US Open (tennis)|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Elisabeth Moore]] defeats [[Myrtle McAteer]] 6–4 3–6 7–5 2–6 6–2 '''Davis Cup''' * 1901 International Lawn Tennis Challenge – {{davis|USA|1896}} walkover {{davis|GBR|name=British Isles}}
==[[Yacht racing]]== '''America's Cup''' * The [[New York Yacht Club]] retains the [[America's Cup]] as ''[[Columbia (1899 yacht)|Columbia]]'' defeats British challenger ''Shamrock II'', of the [[Royal Ulster Yacht Club]], 3 races to 0
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1901 – 1950}}

revision.comment: /* [[Rugby league]] */clean up, replaced: [[York Wasps|York]] → [[York City Knights|York]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1931 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Alpine skiing]]== '''FIS Alpine World Ski Championships'''
Inaugural [[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 1931|FIS Alpine World Ski Championships]] are held at [[Mürren]], Switzerland. The events are a [[Downhill (ski competition)|downhill]] and a [[Slalom skiing|slalom]] race in both the men's and women's categories. The winners are: * Men's Downhill – [[Walter Prager]] (Switzerland) * Men's Slalom – [[David Zogg]] (Switzerland) * Women's Downhill – [[Esme Mackinnon]] (Great Britain) * Women's Slalom – [[Esme Mackinnon]] (Great Britain)
==[[American football]]== * [[1931 Green Bay Packers season|Green Bay Packers]] win [[1931 NFL season|the NFL title]] with a 13–2 record * [[Rose Bowl Game|Rose Bowl]] (1930 season): ** The [[Alabama Crimson Tide football|Alabama Crimson Tide]] won 24-0 over [[Washington State Cougars football|the Washington State Cougars]] to share the college football national championship
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * [[1930–31 Football League|The Football League]] – [[Arsenal FC|Arsenal]] 66 points, [[Aston Villa]] 59, [[Sheffield Wednesday]] 52, [[Portsmouth FC|Portsmouth]] 49, [[Huddersfield Town]] 48, [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] 46 * [[1931 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[West Bromwich Albion]] 2–1 [[Birmingham City]] at [[Wembley Stadium (1924)|Empire Stadium, Wembley, London]] '''Germany''' * [[1931 German football championship|National Championship]] – [[Hertha BSC]] 3–2 [[TSV 1860 München]] at Köln '''Spain''' * [[1930–31 La Liga|La Liga]] won by [[Athletic Bilbao]] '''Italy''' * [[1930–31 Serie A|Serie A]] won by [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] '''Brazil''' * Foundation of [[Botafogo Futebol Clube (PB)|Botafogo Rio]]
==[[Australian rules football]]== * May 9: [[Richmond Football Club|Richmond]] beat [[Sydney Swans|South Melbourne]]’s 12 year record for the highest score when they kick 30.19 (199) to [[North Melbourne Football Club|North Melbourne]]’s 4.7 (31). [[Doug Strang]], in his second game, and [[Jack Titus]] kick 22 goals between them – still an equal record for two players on one side. '''[[1931 VFL season|VFL Premiership]]''' * [[Geelong Football Club|Geelong]] wins the 35th [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership: defeating Richmond 9.14 (68) to 7.6 (48) at [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]] (MCG) * The annual [[Brownlow Medal]] is awarded to [[Haydn Bunton, Sr|Haydn Bunton senior]] ([[Fitzroy Football Club|Fitzroy]]) '''[[South Australian National Football League]]''' * 3 October: [[North Adelaide Football Club|North Adelaide]] 17.13 (115) defeat [[Sturt Football Club|Sturt]] 11.11 (77) to win their sixth SANFL premiership. * [[Magarey Medal]] won by [[Jack Sexton]] ([[West Adelaide Football Club|West Adelaide]]) '''[[1931 WANFL season|Western Australian National Football League]]''' * 1 June: [[East Fremantle Football Club|East Fremantle]]’s 4.28 (52) against [[South Fremantle Football Club|South Fremantle]]’s 5.8 (38) is the second most inaccurate score in WA(N)FL history by excess of behinds over goals and the most until 1957.<ref>[http://australianfootball.com/seasons/inaccurate_scoring/WAFL_129 West Australian Football League: Most Inaccurate Scores]</ref> * 17 October: East Fremantle win their fourth consecutive WA(N)FL premiership, beating [[Subiaco Football Club|Subiaco]] 9.13 (67) to 7.7 (49) in the [[1931 WANFL Grand Final]]. * [[Sandover Medal]] won by [[Lin Richards]] ([[East Fremantle Football Club|East Fremantle]])
==[[Bandy]]== '''Sweden''' * [[Swedish bandy champions|Championship final]] – [[AIK Bandy|AIK]] 4–3 IF Karlstad-Göta
==[[Baseball]]== '''World Series''' * 1–10 October — [[1931 St. Louis Cardinals season|St. Louis Cardinals]] (NL) defeats [[1931 Philadelphia Athletics season|Philadelphia Athletics]] (AL) to win the [[1931 World Series]] by four games to three '''Major League Baseball''' * MVP awards to [[Frankie Frisch]] (NL) and [[Lefty Grove]] (AL) '''Negro League Baseball''' * The [[Negro National League (1920–1931)|Negro National League]] disbands. [[St. Louis Stars (baseball)|St. Louis Stars]] win the last championship.
==[[Basketball]]== '''ABL Championship'''
*[[Brooklyn Visitations]] win four games to two over the [[Fort Wayne Hoosiers]]
'''College Championship''' * [[Northwestern Wildcats men's basketball|Northwestern University]] wins the men's college basketball title
'''Events''' *The ABL suspends operations after the 1930–1931 season. This is also the last year it operates as a major professional league.
==[[Bobsleigh]]== '''Bobsleigh World Championships''' * 2nd [[FIBT World Championships 1931]] are held in [[Oberhof, Germany|Oberhof]], Germany (two-man bob) and [[St Moritz]], Switzerland (four-man bob). Both gold medals are won by Germany.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * [[World Middleweight Champion]] [[Mickey Walker (boxer)|Mickey Walker]] vacates his title to campaign as a heavyweight. The middleweight championship remains vacant until 1941. '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Max Schmeling]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Maxie Rosenbloom]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Mickey Walker (boxer)|Mickey Walker]] → vacant * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – Tommy Freeman → "Young" Jack Thompson → [[Lou Brouillard]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Tony Canzoneri]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – Bat Battalino * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Panama Al Brown]] * [[World Flyweight Champion]]ship – vacant
==[[Canadian football]]== '''Grey Cup''' * [[19th Grey Cup]] in the [[Canadian Football League]] – [[Montreal AAA]] defeats [[Regina Roughriders]] 22–0
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * [[New Zealand national cricket team|New Zealand]] plays its first [[Test cricket|Test series]] in England. [[England national cricket team|England]] wins the series 1–0 with two matches drawn. '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club|Yorkshire]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – [[Leicestershire County Cricket Club|Leicestershire II]] * Most runs – [[Herbert Sutcliffe]] 3006 @ 96.96 (HS 230) * Most wickets – [[Tich Freeman]] 276 @ 15.60 (BB 10–79) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year]] – [[Bill Bowes]], [[Stewie Dempster]], [[James Langridge]], [[Iftikhar Ali Khan Pataudi]], [[Hedley Verity]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[Victoria cricket team|Victoria]] * Most runs – [[Don Bradman]] 1422 @ 79.00 (HS 258) * Most wickets – [[Clarrie Grimmett]] 74 @ 19.14 (BB 7–87) '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular]] – ''not contested'' '''New Zealand''' * [[Plunket Shield]] – [[Canterbury cricket team|Canterbury]] '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – ''not contested'' '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – ''not contested''
==[[Cycling]]== '''Tour de France''' * [[Antonin Magne]] (France) wins the 25th [[1931 Tour de France|Tour de France]] '''Other events''' * [[1930 Giro d'Italia|Giro d'Italia]] is won by [[Francesco Camusso]] (Italy) * [[World Cycling Championship]] is won by [[Learco Guerra]] (Italy)
==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Men's Champion]] – [[Karl Schäfer]] (Austria) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Women's Champion]] – [[Sonja Henie]] (Norway) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Pairs Champions]] – [[Emília Rotter]] and [[László Szollás]] (Hungary)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1931 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Tommy Armour]] * [[1931 U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] – [[Billy Burke (golfer)|Billy Burke]] * [[1931 PGA Championship|PGA Championship]] – [[Tom Creavy]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – Eric Martin-Smith * [[U.S. Amateur]] – [[Francis Ouimet]] * [[Women's Western Open]] – [[June Beebe]]
==[[Harness racing]]== '''USA''' * [[Hambletonian Stakes|Hambletonian]] – Calumet Butler * [[Kentucky Futurity]] – The Protector
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[Champion Hurdle]] – ''not contested due to frost'' * [[Cheltenham Gold Cup]] – ''not contested due to frost'' * [[1931 Grand National|Grand National]] – Grakle * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Four Course]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Cameronian (horse)|Cameronian]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – Cameronian * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Brulette]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Sandwich (horse)|Sandwich]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – White Nose '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Froth Blower '''France''' * [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] – [[Pearl Cap]] '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Impudent Barney * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Sea Serpent '''USA''' * [[1931 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – [[Twenty Grand]] * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Mate * [[Belmont Stakes]] – [[Twenty Grand]]
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Stanley Cup''' * [[1930–31 Montreal Canadiens season|Montreal Canadiens]] defeats [[1930–31 Chicago Black Hawks season|Chicago Black Hawks]] by 3 games to 2 '''Ice Hockey World Championships''' * Gold Medal – [[Canada men's national ice hockey team|Canada]] * Silver Medal – [[United States men's national ice hockey team|United States]] * Bronze Medal – [[Austria men's national ice hockey team|Austria]] '''Other events''' * ''[[Hockey Night in Canada]]'', now the oldest sports-related television program still on air, debuts as a radio program known as the ''General Motors Hockey Broadcast''. The TV series begins in 1952.
==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1931 in motorsport|List of 1931 motorsport champions}}
==[[Nordic skiing]]== '''FIS Nordic World Ski Championships''' * 6th [[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 1931]] are held at [[Oberhof, Germany|Oberhof]], Germany
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 21 March — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 83rd [[The Boat Race 1931|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby league]]== '''England''' * [[Rugby Football League Championship|Championship]] – [[Swinton Lions|Swinton]] * [[Challenge Cup|Challenge Cup final]] – [[Halifax R.L.F.C.|Halifax]] 22–8 [[York City Knights|York]] at [[Wembley Stadium (1924)|Empire Stadium, Wembley, London]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Lancashire League Championship]] – [[Swinton Lions|Swinton]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Yorkshire League Championship]] – [[Leeds Rhinos|Leeds]] * [[RFL Lancashire Cup|Lancashire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[St Helens Recreation RLFC|St Helens Recs]] 18–3 [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] * [[RFL Yorkshire Cup|Yorkshire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Leeds Rhinos|Leeds]] 10–2 [[Huddersfield Giants|Huddersfield]] '''Australia''' * [[New South Wales Rugby League premiership|NSW Premiership]] – [[South Sydney Rabbitohs|South Sydney]] 12–7 [[Sydney Roosters|Eastern Suburbs]]
==[[Rugby union]]== '''Five Nations Championship''' * 44th [[1931 Five Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is won by [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]] * Shortly after the 1931 Five Nations Championship is completed, [[France national rugby union team|France]] is banned from the competition due to allegations of professionalism and administrative deficiencies. France will be readmitted after the [[1939 Home Nations Championship|1939 competition]] but will not be able to play until [[1947 Five Nations Championship|1947]] because of the suspension of international rugby during [[World War II]]. In the meantime, the competition reverts to its original title of Home Nations Championship.
==[[Snooker]]== '''World Championship''' * 5th [[1931 World Snooker Championship|World Snooker Championship]] is won by [[Joe Davis]] who defeats [[Tom Dennis (snooker player)|Tom Dennis]] 25–21
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * [[World Allround Speed Skating Championships for Men|Men's All-round Champion]] – [[Clas Thunberg]] (Finland)
==[[Tennis]]== {{main|1931 in tennis}} '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Jack Crawford (tennis player)|Jack Crawford]] (Australia) defeats [[Harry Hopman]] (Australia) 6–4 6–2 2–6 6–1 * [[List of Australian Open Women's Singles champions|Australian Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Coral Buttsworth]] (Australia) defeats [[Marjorie Cox Crawford]] (Australia) 1–6 6–3 6–4 '''England''' * [[List of Wimbledon Gentlemen's Singles champions|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Sidney Wood]] (USA) by a walkover after [[Frank Shields]] (USA) withdraws from the final due to an ankle injury * [[List of Wimbledon Ladies' Singles champions|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Cilly Aussem]] (Germany) defeats [[Hilde Krahwinkel Sperling]] (Germany) 6–2 7–5 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Jean Borotra]] (France) defeats [[Christian Boussus]] (USA) 2–6 6–4 7–5 6–4 * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Cilly Aussem]] (Germany) defeats [[Betty Nuthall]] (Great Britain) 8–6 6–1 '''USA''' * [[List of US Open Men's Singles champions|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Ellsworth Vines]] (USA) defeats [[George Lott]] (USA) 7–9 6–3 9–7 7–5 * [[List of US Open Women's Singles champions|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Helen Wills Moody]] (USA) defeats [[Eileen Bennett Whittingstall]] (Great Britain) 6–4 6–1 '''Davis Cup''' * [[1931 International Lawn Tennis Challenge]] – {{davis|FRA}} 3–2 {{davis|GBR}} at [[Stade Roland Garros]] (clay) [[Paris]], [[France]]
==Awards== '''Associated Press Athlete of the Year''' * Inauguration of the ''Athlete of the Year'' award in the United States by the Associated Press (AP). The AP offers a male and a female athlete of the year award to either a professional or amateur athlete, the awards being voted on annually by a panel of AP sports editors from across the United States. The first winners are: * [[Associated Press Athlete of the Year#List of award winners|Associated Press Male Athlete of the Year]] – [[Pepper Martin]] (baseball) * [[Associated Press Athlete of the Year#List of award winners|Associated Press Female Athlete of the Year]] – [[Helene Madison]] (swimming)
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1901 – 1950}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1931 in sports| ]]

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Diving]] (link changed to [[Diving (sport)]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=February 2013}} '''1956 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport. {{Year box}}
==[[Alpine skiing]]== * The men's Olympic Gold Medal: ** Downhill: [[Toni Sailer]], Austria ** Slalom: [[Toni Sailer]], Austria ** Giant Slalom: [[Toni Sailer]], Austria * The women's Olympic Gold Medal: ** Downhill: [[Madeleine Berthod]], Switzerland ** Slalom: [[Renée Colliard]], Switzerland ** Giant Slalom: [[Ossi Reichert]], [[West Germany]] * [[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships]]: ** Men's combined champion: [[Toni Sailer]], Austria ** Women's combined champion: [[Madeleine Berthod]], Switzerland
==[[American football]]== * [[1956 NFL Championship Game|NFL Championship]] – [[New York Giants]] won 47-7 over the [[Chicago Bears]] * [[1955 Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl]] (1955 season): ** The [[Oklahoma Sooners]] won 20-6 over the [[Maryland Terrapins]] to win the college football national championship * [[1956 college football season]] ** The [[Oklahoma Sooners]] win the college football national championship (don't participate in a bowl game the following January due to "no-repeat rule") * Montana State and St. Joseph tie for the first ever [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics]] championship game.
==[[Association football]]== * [[UEFA Champions League|European Cup]] – [[Real Madrid]] beat [[Stade de Reims]] 4-3 in the inaugural final.
===England=== * [[Football League First Division|First Division]] – [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] win the [[1955–56 in English football|1955–56]] title. * [[FA Cup]] – [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] beat [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] 3-1. '''Netherlands''' * [[Eredivise]], a premier football league in Holland, a first regular season games held on September 2.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}}
==[[Track and field athletics|Athletics]]== * [[Betty Cuthbert]] (Australia) and [[Bobby Morrow]] (USA) win three gold medals each in the sprint events at the [[1956 Summer Olympics|Olympic Games]] in Melbourne.
==[[Australian rules football]]== * [[Victorian Football League (1897–1989)|Victorian Football League]] ** May 12: [[Stuart Spencer (footballer)|Stuart Spencer]] kicks 0.11 for [[Melbourne Football Club|Melbourne]] against [[Geelong Football Club|Geelong]], equalling the record for the most behinds in a match without scoring a goal. ** July 21: [[Melbourne Football Club|Melbourne]]'s run of nineteen consecutive wins, the fourth highest on record, is ended [[Footscray Football Club|by Footscray]], who score 10.12 (72) to the Demons' 7.17 (59). ** September 15: [[Melbourne Football Club|Melbourne]] wins the 60th VFL Premiership, beating [[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood]] 17.19 (121) to 6.12 (48) [[1956 VFL Grand Final|in the Grand Final]]. ** [[Brownlow Medal]] awarded to [[Peter Box]] ([[Footscray Football Club|Footscray]]) * [[South Australian National Football League]] ** August 4: [[Port Adelaide Magpies Football Club|Port Adelaide]], after starting with thirteen unbeaten games and on target for [[perfect season|a rare unbeaten season]], are unexpectedly beaten [[South Adelaide Football Club|by lowly South Adelaide]] for their only loss of the season. ** September 29: [[Port Adelaide Magpies Football Club|Port Adelaide]] beat [[West Adelaide Football Club|West Adelaide]] for their third successive SANFL premiership, scoring 12.9 (81) to 9.11 (65). * [[West Australian Football League]] ** May 12: [[East Perth Football Club|East Perth]] kick only 1.4 (10) against [[Perth Football Club|Perth]] [[WACA Ground|at the WACA]] in heavy rain, with their lone goal coming in total darkness with three minutes remaining. It is not only the lowest score in the WAFL between 1946 and 2002, but the lowest score by any eventual premier club in a major Australian Rules competition since present-day scoring was introduced in the late 1890s. ** October 13: [[East Perth Football Club|East Perth]] 10.17 (77) defeat [[South Fremantle Football Club|South Fremantle]] 9.10 (64) for their first senior WAFL premiership since 1936.
==[[Baseball]]== * April 17 – [[Luis Aparicio]] replaces fellow [[Venezuela]]n [[Chico Carrasquel]] as the [[Chicago White Sox|White Sox]]' everyday [[shortstop]]. Aparicio, who played 10 seasons with the White Sox, was elected to the [[Baseball Hall of Fame|Hall of Fame]] in [[1984 in sports|1984]] and had his #11 retired by the Sox in the same year. * July 14 – [[Boston Red Sox]] lefty [[Mel Parnell]] pitches a [[no-hitter]] against the [[Chicago White Sox]] at [[Fenway Park]], winning 4-0. It is only Parnell's third win against two losses and is the sixth straight loss for second-place Chicago. The no-hitter is the first for the Red Sox since 1923. Parnell will go 4-4 before a torn muscle in his pitching arm ends his career as the Red Sox' winningest southpaw. * July 25 – [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] outfielder [[Roberto Clemente]] becomes the first (and to date only) player to hit a walk-off inside-the-park grand slam in a win over the [[Chicago Cubs]] at [[Pittsburgh]]'s old [[Forbes Field]]. * [[World Series]] – [[New York Yankees]] win 4 games to 3 over the [[Brooklyn Dodgers]]. Yankees pitcher [[Don Larsen]], pitches the only [[No-hitter|perfect game]] in [[World Series]] history, earning himself [[MLB Most Valuable Player Award|MVP]] honors. It was the only no-hitter thrown in any postseason game until October 6, 2010, in his first postseason appearance, Philadelphia Phillies pitcher Roy Halladay pitched a no-hitter against Cincinnati Reds in the NLDS. * December 1 – [[Cincinnati Reds|Cincinnati]] slugger [[Frank Robinson]] is unanimously voted the [[MLB Rookie of the Year Award|NL Rookie of the Year]]. [[Chicago White Sox|White Sox]] shortstop [[Luis Aparicio]] is voted [[MLB Rookie of the Year Award|AL Rookie of the Year]] with 22 points, beating out [[Baltimore Orioles|Baltimore]]'s [[Tito Francona]] and [[Rocky Colavito]] of the [[Cleveland Indians|Indians]].
==[[Basketball]]== * [[NCAA Men's Basketball Championship]]: ** San Francisco wins 83-71 over Iowa * [[NBA Finals]]: ** [[Philadelphia Warriors]] won 4 games to 1 over the [[Fort Wayne Pistons]]
==[[Boxing]]== * March 19 – At age 48, Dutch boxer [[Bep van Klaveren]] contests his last match in [[Rotterdam]]. * April 27 – [[Rocky Marciano]] retires as the only undefeated Heavyweight Champion of the world with a perfect record (49-0). * November 30, in [[Chicago]] – [[Floyd Patterson]] knocks out [[Archie Moore]] in the 5th round to win the vacant World Heavyweight title.
==[[Canadian football]]== * [[Grey Cup]] – [[Edmonton Eskimos]] win 50-27 over the [[Montreal Alouettes]]
==[[Cycling]]== * [[1956 Giro d'Italia|Giro d'Italia]] won by [[Charly Gaul]] of [[Luxembourg]] * [[1956 Tour de France|Tour de France]] – [[Roger Walkowiak]] of France * [[UCI Road World Championships – Men's road race]] – [[Rik Van Steenbergen]] of Belgium
==[[Field hockey]]== * [[Hockey at the 1956 Summer Olympics|Olympic Games (Men's Competition)]] in [[Melbourne]], Australia ** Gold Medal: India ** Silver Medal: Pakistan ** Bronze Medal: West Germany
==[[Figure skating]]== * [[1956 Winter Olympics]]: ** Men's champion: [[Hayes Alan Jenkins]], United States ** Ladies' champion: [[Tenley Albright]], United States ** Pair skating champions: [[Elisabeth Schwarz]] & [[Kurt Oppelt]], Austria * [[World Figure Skating Championships]]: ** Men's champion: [[Hayes Alan Jenkins]], United States ** Ladies' champion: [[Carol Heiss]], United States ** Pair skating champions: [[Elisabeth Schwarz]] & [[Kurt Oppelt]], Austria ** Ice dancing champions: [[Pamela Weight]] & [[Paul Thomas (skater)]], Great Britain * [[European Figure Skating Championships]]: ** Men's champion: [[Alain Giletti]], France ** Ladies' champion: [[Ingrid Wendl]], Austria ** Pair skating champions: [[Elisabeth Schwarz]] & [[Kurt Oppelt]], Austria ** Ice dancing champions: [[Pamela Weight]] & [[Paul Thomas (skater)]], Great Britain
==[[Golf]]== '''Men's professional''' * [[1956 Masters Tournament|Masters Tournament]] – [[Jack Burke, Jr.]] * [[1956 U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] – [[Cary Middlecoff]] * [[1956 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Peter Thomson (golfer)|Peter Thomson]] * [[1956 PGA Championship]] – [[Jack Burke, Jr.]] * [[PGA Tour]] money leader – [[Ted Kroll]] – $72,836 '''Men's amateur''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[John Beharrell]] * [[U.S. Amateur]] – [[Harvie Ward]] '''Women's professional''' * [[Women's Western Open]] – [[Beverly Hanson]] * [[1956 LPGA Championship|LPGA Championship]] – [[Marlene Hagge]] * [[1956 U.S. Women's Open Golf Championship|U.S. Women's Open]] – [[Kathy Cornelius]] * [[Titleholders Championship]] – [[Louise Suggs]] * [[LPGA|LPGA Tour]] money leader – [[Marlene Hagge]] – $20,235
==[[Harness racing]]== * The [[Triple Crown of Harness Racing for Pacers|United States Pacing Triple Crown races]] is created with the addition of the Messenger Stakes. *# [[Cane Pace]] – [[Noble Adios]] *# [[Little Brown Jug (horse racing)|Little Brown Jug]] – [[Noble Adios]] *# [[Messenger Stakes]] – [[Belle Acton]] * [[Triple Crown of Harness Racing for Trotters|United States Trotting Triple Crown races]]: *# [[Hambletonian Stakes|Hambletonian]] – [[The Intruder (racehorse)|The Intruder]] *# [[Yonkers Trot]] *# [[Kentucky Futurity]] * [[Australian Inter Dominion Harness Racing Championship]]: ** Pacers: [[Gentlemen John]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''Steeplechases''' * [[Cheltenham Gold Cup]] – [[Limber Hill]] * [[1956 Grand National|Grand National]] – [[E.S.B. (horse)|ESB]] '''Flat races''' * Australia – [[Melbourne Cup]] won by [[Evening Peal]] * Canada – [[Queen's Plate]] won by [[Canadian Champ]] * France – [[Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe]] won by [[Ribot (horse)|Ribot]] * Ireland – [[Irish Derby Stakes]] won by [[Talgo (horse)|Talgo]] * [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|English Triple Crown races]]: *# [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Gilles de Retz (horse)|Gilles de Retz]] *# [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Lavandin (horse)|Lavandin]] *# [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Cambremer (horse)|Cambremer]] * [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|United States Triple Crown races]]: *# May 5 – [[1956 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – [[Needles (horse)|Needles]] *# [[1956 Preakness Stakes|Preakness Stakes]] – [[Fabius (horse)|Fabius]] *# [[Belmont Stakes]] – [[Needles (horse)|Needles]]

==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Lew Hoad]] (Australia) defeats [[Ken Rosewall]] (Australia) 6–4, 3–6, 6–4, 7–5 * [[List of Australian Open Women's Singles champions|Australian Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Mary Carter Reitano]] (Australia) defeats [[Thelma Coyne Long]] (Australia) 3–6, 6–2, 9–7 '''England''' * [[List of Wimbledon Gentlemen's Singles champions|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Lew Hoad]] (Australia) defeats [[Ken Rosewall]] (Australia) 6–2, 4–6, 7–5, 6–4 * [[List of Wimbledon Ladies' Singles champions|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Shirley Fry Irvin]] (USA) defeats [[Angela Buxton]] (Great Britain) 6–3, 6–1 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – '''USA''' * [[List of US Open Men's Singles champions|American Men's Singles Championship]] – * [[List of US Open Women's Singles champions|American Women's Singles Championship]] – '''Davis Cup''' * [[1956 Davis Cup]] – {{davis|AUS}} 5–0 {{davis|USA|1912}} at [[Memorial Drive Tennis Centre]] (grass) [[Adelaide]], Australia

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=August 2017}}
[[File:Step Aerobics Class at a Gym.JPG|thumb|Step aerobics in a gym]] [[File:More than 50 Warrior Division Soldiers, military spouses and children gathered at Camp Casey's Carey Fitness Center for dancing, aerobics and fun 110305-A-UQ765-001.jpg|thumb|A dance aerobics class]] '''Aerobics''' is a form of [[physical exercise]] that combines rhythmic [[aerobic exercise]] with [[stretching]] and [[strength training]] routines with the goal of improving all elements of fitness ([[flexibility (anatomy)|flexibility]], [[muscle|muscular]] strength, and [[Circulatory system|cardio-vascular]] fitness). It is usually performed to music and may be practiced in a group setting led by an [[teacher|instructor]] ([[fitness professional]]), although it can be done solo and without musical accompaniment. With the goal of preventing illness and promoting [[physical fitness]], practitioners perform various routines comprising a number of different dance-like exercises. Formal aerobics classes are divided into different levels of intensity and complexity. A well-balanced aerobics class will have five components: warm-up (5–10 minutes), cardio vascular conditioning (25–30 minutes), muscular strength and conditioning (10–15 minutes), cool-down (5–8 minutes) and stretching and flexibility (5–8 minutes). Aerobics classes may allow participants to select their level of participation according to their fitness level. Many gyms offer a variety of aerobic classes. Each class is designed for a certain level of experience and taught by a certified instructor with a specialty area related to their particular class.
==History== [[Image:Aqua Aerobics.JPG|thumb|A water aerobics class at an Aquatic Centre.]] Both the term and the specific exercise method were developed by Dr [[Kenneth H. Cooper]], an exercise physiologist, and Col. Pauline Potts, a physical therapist, both of the [[United States Air Force]]. Cooper, an exercise enthusiast, was puzzled about why some people with good muscular strength were prone to perform poorly at activities such as long-distance running, swimming, and bicycling. He began using a [[bicycle ergometer]] to measure sustained performance in terms of a person's ability to use oxygen. In 1968, he published ''Aerobics'', which included exercise programs using running, walking, swimming and bicycling. At the time the book was published there was increasing awareness of the need for increased exercise due to widespread weakness and inactivity. Cooper published a mass-market version "''The New Aerobics''" in 1979.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/news/press-releases/aerobics-kenneth-cooper-to-receive-harvard-healthy-cup-award/|title=“Father of Aerobics” Kenneth Cooper, MD, MPH to receive Healthy Cup Award from Harvard School of Public Health|date=2008-04-16|work=News|access-date=2018-10-08|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.clubindustry.com/forprofits/dr-kenneth-cooper-and-how-he-became-known-father-aerobics|title=Dr. Kenneth Cooper and How He Became Known as the Father of Aerobics|date=2008-09-01|work=Club Industry|access-date=2018-10-08}}</ref>
Aerobics gained worldwide popularity after the release of [[Jane Fonda]]'s exercise videos in 1982.
== Step aerobics == {{Unreferenced section|date=July 2016}} Step aerobics is a form of aerobic exercise that uses a low elevated platform, the step, of height tailored to individual needs by inserting risers. Step aerobics classes are offered at many gyms.
Step aerobics was developed by Gin Miller around 1989. After a knee injury, Miller consulted with an orthopedic doctor, who recommended she strengthen the muscles supporting the knee by stepping up and down on a milk crate; from this she developed the step regimen. [[File:Aerobics class.jpg|thumb|Aerobics class]] Step aerobics can also be involved in dancing games, such as ''[[Dance Dance Revolution]]'' or ''[[In the Groove (video game)|In the Groove]]''.
===Moves and techniques=== Often moves are referred to as [[Reebok]] step moves in reference to one of the first makers of the plastic step commonly used in gyms.
The "basic" step involves raising one foot onto the step, then the other so that they are both on the step, then stepping the first foot back, followed by the second. A "right basic" would involve stepping right foot up, then the left, then returning to the floor alternating right then left.
Some instructors switch immediately between different moves, for example between a right basic and a left basic without any intervening moves, effectively "tapping" the foot without shifting weight; tap-free or smooth stepping alternates the feet without "taps"
[[Image:the step.jpg|thumb|a step with 2 risers]] Common moves include:
*Basic Step *Corner knee (or corner kick) *Repeater knee (aka Triple knee) *T-Step *Over-the-Top *Lunges *V-Step *Straddle Down *L-Step *Split Step *I-Step
===Choreography=== Many instructors will prepare a set of moves that will be executed together to form the choreography of the class. Usually, the choreography will be timed to 32 beats in a set, ideally switching legs so that the set can be repeated in a mirrored fashion. A set may consist of many different moves and the different moves may have different durations. For example, a basic step as described above takes 4 beats (for the 4 steps the person takes). Similarly, the "knee up" move also takes 4 beats. Another common move, the repeater knee, is an 8-beat move.
Classes vary in the level of choreography. Basic level classes will tend to have a series of relatively basic moves strung together into a sequence. More advanced classes incorporate dance elements such as turns, mambos, and stomps. These elements are put together into 2–3 routines in each class. One learns the routines during the class and then all are performed at the end of the class. Regardless of the complexity of the choreography, most instructors offer various options for different levels of intensity/dance ability while teaching the routines.
== Freestyle aerobics == [[File:Exercices d'aérobic.jpg|thumb|An Aerobics class]] '''Freestyle aerobics''' is an aerobics style in which a group instructor choreographs several short dance combinations and teaches them to the class. This is usually achieved by teaching the class 1-2 movements at a time and repeating the movements until the class is able to join the whole choreography together. Aerobic music is used throughout the class. This is sometimes followed by a strength section which uses body weight exercises to strengthen muscles and a stretch routine to cool down and improve [[flexibility]]. Classes are usually 30–60 minutes in length and may include the use of equipment such as a barbell, [[aerobics|aerobic]] step, or small weights.
In freestyle aerobics, the instructor choreographs the routine and adjusts it to the needs and wants of her/his class. There is often no difference between base movements in freestyle and pre-choreographed programs.
It is practiced to improve aerobic fitness, [[flexibility (anatomy)|flexibility]] and strength.
==Aerobic gymnastics== [[File:figuraaerobic.jpg|thumb|right|A sport aerobics team]] [[Aerobic gymnastics]], also known as [[sport aerobics]] and [[Competition#Sports|competitive]] aerobics, may combine complicated [[choreography]], [[rhythmic gymnastics|rhythmic]] and [[acrobatic gymnastics]] with elements of aerobics.<ref>{{cite web|title=About Aerobic|url=https://www.fig-gymnastics.com/site/page/view?id=277|website=Fédération Internationale de Gymnastique|accessdate=9 June 2014}}</ref> Performance is divided into categories by age, sex and groups (individual, mixed pairs and trios) and are judged on the following elements: dynamic and static strength, jumps and leaps, kicks, balance and flexibility. Ten exercises are mandatory: four consecutive high leg kicks, patterns. A maximum of ten elements from following families are allowed: [[push-ups]], supports and balances, kicks and splits, jumps and leaps. Elements of [[tumbling (gymnastics)|tumbling]] such as [[Handspring (gymnastics)|handsprings]], [[handstand]]s, [[flip (acrobatic)|back flips]], and aerial [[somersault]]s are prohibited. Scoring is by judging of artistic quality, creativity, execution, and difficulty of routines. Sport aerobics has state, national, and international competitions, but is not an olympic sport.
==Benefits== Like other forms of exercise, step aerobics helps burn calories and fat. The number of calories burned depends on the speed of movements, step height, length of exercise, and the persons height and weight.
==See also== {{Commons category|Aerobic exercise}} *[[Water aerobics]] *[[Yoga postures]]
==References== {{Reflist}} <!--added under references heading by script-assisted edit-->
{{Physical exercise}}
[[Category:Aerobic exercise|*]] [[Category:Physical exercise]] [[Category:1980s fads and trends]]

{{Refimprove|date=February 2016}} A '''benefit''' is a match or season of activities granted by a sporting body to a loyal sportsman to boost their income before retirement. Often this is in the form of a match for which all the ticket proceeds are given to the player in question. However hosting one of these matches is a risk for the player in question as he/she is responsible for paying any relevant receipts and collects any excess income from the match, therefore income from such matches is more often than not reliant on attendance.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|url = http://www.tandfonline.com.ipacez.nd.edu.au/doi/abs/10.1080/09523369908714056#.VS4qvpSUcmV|title = County cricketers’ benefits and testimonials, 1946–85,|last = Sadiford & Vamplew|first = Keith A.P & Wray|date = 1999|journal = The International Journal of the History of Sport|doi = 10.1080/09523369908714056|pmid = |access-date = }}</ref>
Sometimes, the "beneficiary" can opt to give part or all of the money to charity. An example of this is [[Paul Collingwood]]'s 2007 benefit with [[Durham County Cricket Club]]. This may also occur when sportsmen unite for a cause, for example the [[Rafael Nadal]] vs [[Roger Federer]] "[[Match for Africa]]" (2010) where more than $2.6 million was raised for the [[Roger Federer Foundation]], enabling children living in poverty to realise their potential.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.match-for-africa.com/en/|title = Match for Africa 2|date = 2014|accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.rogerfedererfoundation.org/en/home/|title = Roger Federer Foundation|date = 2015|accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.atpworldtour.com/News/Tennis/2010/12/Other/Charity-Nadal-Federer-In-Madrid.aspx|title = Nadal, Federer Unite For Children In Madrid|date = 2010|accessdate = |website = ATP World Tour|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
== History == Benefit matches originated in English [[county cricket]] in a time period where playing sport, in particular cricket, for a living didn't offer as big of an income as it does in modern society (2015), holding a benefit at a player's 10 year service mark or retirement mark was considered a form of retirement/insurance policy. Benefit matches are confused with [[Testimonial match]]es, it's important to note that this is a direct gift from the club where income is guaranteed unlike in a benefit where income is often dependent on attendance.<ref name=":0" /> Similar events were organised in Baseball in the 1860s, these events often occurred at season end involving the stars of the sport to acknowledge a significant member of the sport. However a rule established by the NABBP in 1859 prohibited any player compensation, the basis of this rule was to maintain fair game in competition and avoid professional vs. amateur situations arising.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title = Early Professional Baseball and The Sporting Press|last = Furst|first = R. Terry|publisher = McFarland|year = 2014|isbn = 9781476606255|location = |pages = 110, 116, 117, 122}}</ref>
== Significant matches ==
=== Cricket === *1933, [[Don Blackie]] and [[Bert Ironmonger]]<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url =http://trove.nlBert|title =The Sydney Morning Herald (NSW : 1842 - 1954)|last =|first =|date =|work =|access-date =|via =}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> *1934, [[T. J. E. Andrews]], [[Herbie Collins]], and [[Charles Kelleway]]<ref name=":2" /> *1948, [[Stan Squires]] benefit match <ref>{{Cite book|title = The Bedsers: Twinning Triumphs|last = Hill|first = Alan|publisher = Random House|year = 2012|isbn = 9781780574141|location = |pages = chapter 5}}</ref>
=== Baseball === *1861, Creighton & Pierce <ref name=":1" />
== See also == *[[Testimonial match|Testimonial Match]] *[[Benefit season|Benefit Season]]
== References == <references />

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=April 2017}}
A '''big way''' is a type of [[formation skydiving]] involving a large group of skydivers coming together while in [[freefall]] to form a specific and predetermined formation. All the skydivers involved aim to connect with each other and hold the complete formation for a designated period (a number of seconds).
A sequential skydive would involve multiple formations. Grips between individual skydivers can be on any part of the hand/arm or legs. The jumpsuits worn are specifically designed with handle-like grips to assist.
There is a lot of behind the scenes work prior to organization of any big way event. This includes not only the invitation of individual skydivers, but also the coordination of aircraft, pilots, freefall and ground cameras as well as all support and ground staff.
== Size ==
The number of skydivers needed for a formation skydive to be considered a "big way" is often a contentious issue. It often depends on what is considered normal at each [[dropzone]]. For a small dropzone operating only a small [[Cessna]] aircraft that seats 5 people, anything over 5 may be considered "big". However, for dropzones with aircraft that take more people, 6 would be considered small. There are courses available for skydivers to train to jump on formations of 100 or greater.
The largest formation ever built was the 400-way created and held over [[Udon Thani]], [[Thailand]] on February 8, 2006.<ref name=p400>"[http://www.fai.org/fai-record-file/?recordId=13052 G-2 Parachuting, Performance Records. Large freefall formation] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924043503/http://www.fai.org/fai-record-file/?recordId=13052 |date=2015-09-24 }}". [[Fédération Aéronautique Internationale]] (FAI). Accessed: 21 September 2014.</ref>
== Locations ==
Big-way formation skydiving takes place all over the world, at many dropzones. For a large formation (fifty plus) the skydivers can be a group gathered from around the country, or in many cases the world, bringing together their expertise, extreme effort and drive to meet a challenge.
Team Awesome is an example of an international big-way skydiving club with members from many countries, traveling around the world to participate in big-way skydiving.
==References== {{reflist|1}}
[[Category:Sports terminology]]

{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = California State
Athletic Control Board |logo = Seal of California.svg |logo_width = 150px |logo_caption = California State Seal |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |formed = |preceding1 = |jurisdiction = [[California]] |headquarters = 2005 Evergreen Street, Suite 2010, Sacramento, CA 95815 |employees = |budget = |chief1_name = John Carvelli[http://www.dca.ca.gov/csac/about_us/commisnr_bios.shtml Commissioner Biographies] URL accessed on December 6, 2011. |chief1_position = Chairman |chief2_name = Mary Lehman |chief2_position = Vice-Chairman |chief3_name = [[Andy Foster]] |chief3_position = Executive Officer |parent_agency = [[California Department of Consumer Affairs]] |website = [http://www.dca.ca.gov/csac/index.shtml Official Site] |footnotes = Commissioners Martha Shen-Urquidez, Dr. Vernon Williams, Van Gordon Sauter, Luis Ayala }} The '''California State Athletic Commission''' (CSAC) regulates amateur and [[professional boxing]], amateur and professional [[kickboxing]] and professional [[mixed martial arts]] (MMA) throughout the State by licensing all participants and supervising the events. ==See also== {{portal|Martial Arts|California}} *[[Association of Boxing Commissions]] *[[Mixed martial arts rules]] == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.dca.ca.gov/csac/index.shtml}} [[Category:Boxing in California]] [[Category:State agencies of California|Athletic Commission]] [[Category:Sports law]] [[Category:Athletic commissions in the United States]] {{boxing-stub}}

A '''Cann table''' or '''Visual league table''', is a method of displaying data in a [[league table]].
The purpose of the table is to give some idea of the actual points gap between the teams in the league by listing them next to their current points total. Where teams are tied on points, teams are then ranked by goal difference from left to right and games played are shown in brackets. Unlike a traditional league table, a row is left blank if no team has the corresponding number of points.
It is named posthumously after Jenny Cann, an [[Arsenal F.C.]] supporter who published the style, a ''visual table'', on her website the 'Clock End'<ref>{{cite web|last=Lyons |first=Keith |title=Jenny Cann|url=https://keithlyons.me/blog/2018/04/10/jenny-cann/|accessdate=10 April 2018|date=10 April 2018}}</ref> from 1998. She died in 2003.<ref>{{cite web|title=One To Go: What to Watch For in the Final Weekend of EPL Action|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/zachslaton/2012/05/10/one-to-go-what-to-watch-for-in-the-final-weekend-of-epl-action/|publisher=Forbes.com|accessdate=17 January 2014|date=5 October 2012}}</ref>
==Example==
{| class="wikitable" !Points !Team (Matches played) |- |52||Arsenal (24) |- |51|| |- |50|| |- |49|| |- |48|| |- |47||Manchester United (24) |- |46|| |- |45||Newcastle United (24) |- |44|| |- |43|| |- |42|| |- |41||Chelsea (24) |- |40|| |- |39||Everton (24) |- |38||Liverpool (24) ; Tottenham Hotspur (24) |- |37|| |- |36||Southampton (24) |- |35|| |- |34||Blackburn Rovers (24) ; Manchester City (24) |- |33||Charlton Athletic (24) |- |32 || |- |31||Leeds United (24) |- |30||Middlesbrough (24) |- |29||Aston Villa (24) |- |28 || |- |27||Fulham (23) |- |26||Birmingham City (24) |- |25 || |- |24 || |- |23 || |- |22 || |- |21||Bolton Wanderers (24) |- |20 || |- |19||Sunderland (24) |- |18 || |- |17||West Bromwich Albion (23) |- |16||West Ham United (24) |}

[[Category:Sports terminology]]

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} In many [[sport]]s, a '''competition number''' is used to identify and differentiate the competitors taking part in the competitive endeavour. For example, runners in a race may wear a prominent competition number so that they may be clearly identified from a distance. It is also called a '''bib number''' when worn on a [[Bib (garment)|bib]] over, or affixed to, the athlete's top.
==Vehicles== In [[motorsport]], competition numbers are attached to the vehicles taking part, also for identification. In some types of motorsport such as [[rallying|rallyes]], the competition number works in conjunction with special kinds of timing system (for example [[targa timing]]) and as a result numbers also usually relate to the competitors' [[due time]] and thus may exhibit gaps such as skipping from number 59 to number 100 (59 minutes to 1 hour due time).
==Athletics== Since the 2000s, [[track and field]] athletes at major competitions wear their names as well as their numbers on their bibs. In relay events, all team members have the [[IOC country code]]. [[Track event|Track]] athletes also wear a lane number on the shorts.
===Gallery=== <gallery> File:Olympic Games 1980 - 5000 m race.jpg|[[Athletics at the 1980 Summer Olympics – Men's 5000 metres|1980 Olympic 5000m]] Competition numbers on bibs File:Aselefech Mergia 6618.jpg| [[2009 World Championships in Athletics – Women's marathon|2009 World marathon]] Surname on front of bib File:3000 steeple final Berlin 2009.jpg | [[2009 World Championships in Athletics – Men's 3000 metres steeplechase|2009 World steeplechase]] Number on back of bib File:4 x 400 m Jamaica Berlin 2009.JPG| [[2009 World Championships in Athletics – Women's 4 × 400 metres relay|2009 World 4 × 400 m relay]] JAM for the Jamaican team </gallery>
==See also== *[[Number (sports)]] *[[Name (sports)]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Competition Number}} [[Category:Numbering in sports|*]]
